key_ordering.rule: Always start with the root note as the leftmost key
key_ordering.explanation: This provides visual consistency and makes it easier to identify the chord's root

highlighting: When highlighting a note that has a sharp/flat equivalent (e.g., F# vs Gb), use the appropriate enharmonic spelling based on the chord's root note
Always highlight both the natural note and its sharp/flat equivalent when they represent the same chord tone
For black keys that are chord tones, highlight them with the same color as white keys (#ff9999)
chord_naming: Use lowercase 'i' for minor chords in roman numerals
Use uppercase 'I' for major chords in roman numerals
Include both roman numeral and actual chord name in progression labels (e.g., 'i - Am')

D_major.key_order: Start with D, then arrange other white keys (E, F, G, A, B, C) and black keys in order
D_major.notes: D major triad consists of D (root), F# (major third), and A (perfect fifth)

E_minor.key_order: Start with E, then arrange other white keys (F, G, A, B, C, D) and black keys in order
E_minor.notes: E minor triad consists of E (root), G (minor third), and B (perfect fifth)

B7.key_order: Start with B, then arrange other white keys (C, D, E, F, G, A) and black keys in order
B7.notes: B7 consists of B (root), D# (major third), F# (perfect fifth), and A (minor seventh)
